channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: India Ink: Low-Cost Water Is Hard Sell in Delhi Colony
item.description: In a resettlement colony on the outskirts of New Delhi, “water A.T.M.s” provide clean drinking water around the clock, but residents would rather wait for the free tankers that come once a day.
item.dc:creator: By VISHNU VARMA
item.media:description: Bunty Kumar gets drinking water from automatic vending machines in Sawda Ghevra, a resettlement colony on the outskirts of New Delhi.

item.title: Lens Blog: Bringing the Nigerian Schoolgirls Into View
item.description: The plight of the kidnapped girls has eclipsed a basic question: Who are these young women? A photographer discovered clues in their belongings.
item.category: The New York Times Lens Blog
item.dc:creator: By JAMES ESTRIN
item.media:description: An article of clothing owned by Comfort Ngala Bullus, one of the more than 200 girls who were kidnapped on April 15.

item.title: President’s Choice for South Korea Premier Steps Aside
item.description: The former justice’s decision, after a string of revelations that tarnished his image, is a blow to the beleaguered government of President Park Geun-hye.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: India Ink: A Conversation With: Yogendra Yadav, a Leader of the Aam Aadmi Party
item.description: India Ink spoke with the Aam Aadmi chief spokesman about what he regards as his party’s disappointing performance in the national elections.
item.dc:creator: By VAIBHAV VATS

item.title: Obama to Defend Foreign Policy in West Point Speech
item.description: In the wake of criticism that he has been too lax in the face of war and terrorism, the president is to address his vision in a commencement address Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: The Living Ghosts of Moscow
item.description: In the five months since I left, Russia has changed: Many of those who can are thinking about emigrating.
item.dc:creator: By MASHA GESSEN

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: García Márquez’s Blind Spot
item.description: It would have been a poetic act of justice if — in the autumn of his life — he had distanced himself from Fidel Castro.
item.dc:creator: By ENRIQUE KRAUZE

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: As Goes Greece, So Goes Europe?
item.description: Extremist parties are eroding the center-left and center-right core of national and E.U. politics.
item.dc:creator: By NIKOS KONSTANDARAS

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Violence Leads Xinjiang to Propose Paying Tourists to Visit
item.description: The authorities in the region of Xinjiang, which has been hit by a series of terrorist attacks targeting civilians, are considering offering cash bonuses to tourists from other parts of China this summer.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.media:description: Officials are hoping tourists can be induced to return to Xinjiang. Here a billboard promoting the construction of a theater on the outskirts of Kashgar last year says: "Adil, the King of Wire Walking, Welcomes You to Yengi Sheher."

item.title: French Police Expel Migrants from Makeshift Camps
item.description: The move came days after European elections that benefited anti-immigrant parties, although officials said the timing of the expulsions was a coincidence.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Tibetan Protest Singer Is Said to Be Under Arrest
item.description: The singer, Gebe, was detained last week by the Chinese authorities in Sichuan Province, reports say, after a concert at which he performed songs from his banned album.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By AMY QIN

item.title: Syrians Abroad Vote in Advance of National Ballot
item.description: Thousands of Syrians who have fled to Lebanon were among expatriates participating in an election expected to return President Bashar al-Assad to power.
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD and ALAN COWELL
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Men registered to vote on Wednesday at the Syrian embassy in Baabda, Lebanon.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Hong Kong Considers Limits on Mainland Chinese Visitors
item.description: As a politically volatile summer nears, Hong Kong’s leader floats the idea of reducing the number of visits by mainland Chinese.
item.dc:creator: By GERRY MULLANY
item.media:description: Last year there were 40 million mainland visits to Hong Kong, an increase of 16.7 percent from 2012.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Elderly Suicides Reported After City Announces Phase-out on Burials
item.description: A spate of elderly suicides has followed announcement of a government phase-out of full burials in favor of cremation around the city of Anqing, the Chinese news media reported.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: A man laid a flower at the tomb of a relative during the Qingming, or Tomb Sweeping, Festival in April.

item.title: Patient Is Held After Fire at South Korea Hospital Kills 21
item.description: Most of the victims were patients in their 70s and 80s, many of whom had been hospitalized for dementia or stroke complications.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: After Vote Upset, E.U. Grapples With Filling a Key Post
item.description: European Union Leaders consigned a decision about who should lead its most important agency to a potentially lengthy process after upstart parties surged in voting.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES KANTER

item.title: World Briefing: Sierra Leone: Ebola Virus Spreads From Guinea
item.description: One death in a village near the border with Guinea has been confirmed by a laboratory as Ebola, and four other deaths are considered suspect.
item.dc:creator: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.

item.title: World Briefing: South Sudan: U.N. Shifts Focus of Its Mandate
item.description: The United Nations Security Council passed a resolution on Tuesday that shifts its peacekeeping operations in South Sudan toward safeguarding civilians.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: World Briefing: Libya: State Dept. Urges Americans to Leave
item.description: The State Department cited the fighting among militias in urging Americans against traveling to Libya and asking those already there to leave.
item.dc:creator: By STEVE KENNY

item.title: Amid Split on Bank Case, U.S. Seeks a Middle Path
item.description: Solicitor General Donald Verrilli Jr. recently asked the Supreme Court not to intervene in a lawsuit in which American victims of terrorist attacks in Israel are accusing Jordan’s Arab Bank of providing services to terrorists.
item.dc:creator: By CHARLIE SAVAGE

item.title: World Briefing: Iran: Supreme Leader Pushes Fertility Campaign
item.description: Ayatollah Ali Khamenei has called for a population increase, an edict likely to restrict access to contraception.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Fringe Group in Britain Forces Others to Listen
item.description: The United Kingdom Independence Party, which performed well in last week’s voting, has prompted politicians to recalibrate their positions in time for next May’s general election.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER and STEPHEN CASTLE
item.media:description: Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain arriving for a dinner in Brussels on Tuesday.

item.title: Win by Far-Right Party Rattles the French Establishment
item.description: The stark victory of the National Front in European Parliament elections has eroded support for President François Hollande’s policies and called France’s power into question.
item.dc:creator: By LIZ ALDERMAN
item.media:description: Marine Le Pen’s party, the far-right National Front, earned a stark victory in European Parliament elections last week.

item.title: 21 Die in Fire at Hospital in South Korea
item.description: The victims were mostly older dementia patients, and their deaths further traumatized a country still shaken by the recent ferry disaster.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Nigeria Denies Formal Talks on Captive Schoolgirls
item.description: A government spokesman did not rule out some type of discussion with people in contact with Boko Haram to try to win the freedom of hundreds of kidnapped schoolgirls.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By ADAM NOSSITER
